description:
Euleptes europaea, commonly known as the European leaf-toed gecko, is a small species of gecko found in the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Sphaerodactylidae, which includes some of the smallest lizards in the world.

Euleptes europaea is a delicate, slender gecko with a flattened body and a relatively large head. It has large, round eyes and a characteristic tail that is typically longer than its body. The gecko's toes are expanded at the tips, which aid in its ability to climb vertically on various surfaces. The coloration of Euleptes europaea is typically light brown or gray, sometimes with darker markings or patterns, which help it camouflage in its natural habitat.

This species is found in rocky, mountainous areas, often in crevices, under stones, or in the nooks and crannies of old buildings. It is primarily nocturnal and feeds on small invertebrates, such as insects and spiders. Euleptes europaea is considered a habitat specialist, as it is adapted to live in the specific environmental conditions of the Mediterranean region.

Conservation-wise, the European leaf-toed gecko is classified as Least Concern by the IUCN, as it has a relatively wide distribution and is not facing significant threats at the moment. However, it is important to maintain the integrity of its natural habitats to ensure the long-term survival of this unique and fascinating lizard species.
